[[impressionism]][http://www.kaluga.ru/bill/event/13285 kaluga.ru] | works = | patrons = | awards = }} '''Joseph Andreyevich Pavlishak''' ({{lang-rus|Иосиф Андреевич Павлишак}};[http://www.art.kaluga.ru/about/?content=doc&id=10 art.kaluga.ru] September 20, 1923, [[Kaluga]] — September 27, 1995, [[Kaluga]]) was a Soviet and Russian painter and teacher. He was a member of the [[USSR Union of Artists]] since 1953. {{Interlanguage link multi|Honored Painter of Russia|ru|3=Заслуженный художник РСФСР}}. He participated in the [[Great Patriotic War]].[http://jhorosho.ru/soby-tiya/svetskaya-hronika/iosif-pavlishak-brilliantovaya-kollektsiya/ jhorosho.ru] He was a participant of the All-Union exhibition of the I Congress of painters in [[Moscow]] (1957). Shortly before his death, he was introduced to the title of [[People's Artist of the Russian Federation]], but he did not get an estimate. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://pavlishak.ru Official Site] * [http://www.art.kaluga.ru/members/?content=artist&id=98 Biography] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pavlishak, Joseph}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Russian painters]] [[Category:Russian male painters]] [[Category:Soviet painters]] [[Category:Socialist realism]] [[Category:Socialist realism artists]] [[Category:People from Kaluga]] [[Category:Russian portrait painters]] [[Category:Russian landscape painters]] [[Category:Russian realist painters]] [[Category:Russian still life painters]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Patriotic War, 1st class]] [[Category:Russian Jews]]

{{Other uses|King Mob (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} '''King Mob''' was an [[England|English]] radical group based in [[London]] during the late 1960s/early 1970s.<ref>http://www.tate.org.uk/context-comment/articles/mob-who-shouldnt-really-be-here</ref>
It was a cultural mutation of the [[Situationist International|Situationists]] and the anarchist group [[UAW/MF]]. It sought to emphasise the cultural anarchy and disorder being ignored in [[UK|Britain]], with the ultimate aim of promoting [[proletarian]] revolution. It derived its name from [[Christopher Hibbert]]'s 1958 book on the [[Gordon Riots]] of June 1780, in which rioters daubed the [[slogan]] "His Majesty King Mob" on the walls of [[Newgate Prison]], after gutting the building.
==Actions== King Mob appreciated pop culture and distributed its ideas and [[politics|political]] ideas through various posters and through its publication ''King Mob Echo'', which provoked reaction by celebrating killers like [[Jack the Ripper]], [[Mary Bell]] and [[John Christie (murderer)|John Christie]]. One flyer in particular celebrated [[Valerie Solanas]]' 1968 shooting of [[Andy Warhol]] and included a hit-list of [[Yoko Ono]], [[Mick Jagger]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Richard Hamilton (artist)|Richard Hamilton]], [[Mario Amaya]] (who was also shot by Solanas), [[David Hockney]], [[Mary Quant]], [[Twiggy]], [[Marianne Faithfull]] and the ''[[International Times|IT]]'' editor [[Barry Miles]].
The King Mob group allegedly planned a series of audacious actions, including blowing up a waterfall in the [[Lake District]], painting the poet [[Wordsworth]]'s house with the words "[[Samuel Taylor Coleridge|Coleridge]] Lives", and hanging peacocks in [[Holland Park]], London.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cooper|first=Sam|date=2013-03-01|title=The Peculiar Romanticism of the English Situationists|url=http://camqtly.oxfordjournals.org/content/42/1/20|journal=The Cambridge Quarterly|language=en|volume=42|issue=1|pages=20–37|doi=10.1093/camqtly/bft010|issn=0008-199X}}</ref> However, none of the aforementioned plans were executed. An action that was carried out, inspired by the New York-based [[Black Mask (anarchists)|Black Mask]]'s "mill-in at [[Macy's]]", involved King Mob appearing at the [[Selfridges]] store in London, with one member, dressed as [[Father Christmas]], attempting to distribute all of the store's toys to children. Police subsequently forced the children to return the toys. This action involved [[Malcolm McLaren]] who reputedly applied the group's situationist ideas in the promotion of the [[Sex Pistols]].<ref>http://www.stewarthomesociety.org/ass/punk.htm</ref>
King Mob was also responsible for attacks on art galleries and for organising a battle between local [[skinhead]]s (whom they considered to be "the working class avant-garde") and [[Greaser (subculture)|greasers]] in central London.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
==Graffiti== Graffiti attributed to King Mob was observed in many places particularly in the [[Notting Hill]] area, including, "''I don't believe in nothing - I feel like they ought to burn down the world - just let it burn down baby.''"
The most celebrated graffiti attributed to King Mob was the slogan which was painted along a half-mile section of the wall beside the tube (railway) commuter route into London between [[Ladbroke Grove tube station|Ladbroke Grove]] and [[Westbourne Park tube station]]s in west London:
:"''Same thing day after day- tube - work - dinner - work - tube - armchair - TV - sleep - tube - work - how much more can you take? - one in ten go mad, one in five cracks up.''"<ref>http://www.revoltagainstplenty.com/index.php/archive-local/128-a-hidden-history-of-king-mob-posterscartoons.html</ref>
==References in popular culture== The "Mask of King Mob" can be seen in the background of the comic book ''[[Watchmen]]'', written by [[Alan Moore]]. It is in what appears to be a trophy room of the Minutemen, noticeable during the infamous scene where The Comedian tries to rape the original Silk Specter.
A protagonist in the comic book series ''[[The Invisibles]]'' (authored by [[Grant Morrison]]) is codenamed "[[King Mob (comics)|King Mob]]". The Invisibles is organized anti-hierarchically, and is dedicated to defeating a global conspiracy which deceives and preys upon the world's population. The character "King Mob" describes himself as an anarchist.
Graffiti referencing King Mob appears in season 2 episode 7 of Stranger Things.
==See also== *[[Anti-art]] *[[The Angry Brigade]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== Sources == *"The End of Music", a pamphlet written by David and Stuart Wise in the mid- to late-1970s and published in Glasgow. The text was later reprinted by [[AK Press]] in the 1990s as part of [[Stewart Home]]'s book ''What is Situationism? A Reader''. *''King Mob. Nosotros, el Partido del Diablo'', Spanish compilation of King Mob texts, edited by La Felguera Ediciones in 2007 *''The Situationist International in Britain: Modernism, Surrealism, and the Avant-Gardes'' (Routledge 2016)

{{Italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Profile of a Young Fiancee - da Vinci.jpg | caption = | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 300px | title = La Bella Principessa | alt = A young woman in profile, looking to the left. | other_language_1 = [[English language|English]] | other_title_1 = The Beautiful Princess | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Uncertain. Disputed attribution to [[Leonardo da Vinci]] | year = 1495-6<ref group =note>The vellum has been carbon dated to between 1440 – 1650, within a 95 % confidence interval. The 1495–96 is the dating by Kemp.</ref> | type = [[Trois crayons]] (black, red and white chalk), heightened with pen and ink on [[vellum]], laid on oak panel | condition = Restored | subject = Bianca Sforza<ref group =note>If by Leonardo; see text.</ref> | height_metric = 33 | width_metric = 23.9 | length_metric = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = | museum = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = Private collection }} '''''La Bella Principessa''''' (English: "The Beautiful Princess"), also known as Portrait of Bianca Sforza, '''''Young Girl in Profile in Renaissance Dress''''' and '''''Portrait of a Young Fiancée''''', is a portrait in coloured chalks and ink, on [[vellum]], of a young lady in fashionable costume and hairstyle of a [[Milan]]ese of the 1490s.<ref name=MK/> Sold for just under [[U.S. Dollars|$]]22,000 at [[auction]] on January 30, 1998 at Christie's Auction in New York City, the portrait was catalogued as early 19th-century German work. In 2007, Peter Silverman, purchased the portrait from a gallery on East 73rd Street, owned by Kate Ganz. Peter Silverman believed that the portrait was possibly from an older period, potentially dating back to the Renaissance period, and some experts have since attributed it to [[Leonardo da Vinci]]. In 2010 one of those experts, [[Martin Kemp (art historian)|Martin Kemp]], made it the subject of his book ''La Bella Principessa: The Story of the New Masterpiece by Leonardo da Vinci''.<ref name=study/> According to Pascal Cotte and Martin Kemp, the sheet could have been cut from a Milanese book of which the remainder has long been in [[Warsaw]], which comes from the ''milieu'' of [[Ludovico Sforza]], Leonardo's employer.<ref name="Lumiere">{{cite web|url=http://www.lumiere-technology.com/discoveries2.html |title=New Leonardo da Vinci Bella Principessa confirmed |publisher=Lumiere-technology.com |date=28 September 2011 |accessdate=2013-07-23}}</ref>
The attribution to Leonardo da Vinci has been disputed.<ref name="G1">{{cite journal|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/07/12/100712fa_fact_grann?currentPage=all |title=The Mark of a Masterpiece|last=Grann|first=David|authorlink=David Grann|journal=[[The New Yorker]]|volume=LXXXVI|issue= 20|date= July 12–19, 2010|issn=0028-792X}}</ref> In 2011, the ''New Yorker'' published an article about Paul Biro and revealed he had attempted and succeeded to authenticate many fakes knowingly.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2010/07/12/the-mark-of-a-masterpiece|title=The Prints in the Paint|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref> He was condemned but "authenticated" ''La Bella Princessa'' and was endorsed by Martin Kemp and Pascal Cotte.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boowiki.info/art/les-historiens-d-art-britanniques/martin-kemp-historien-d-art.html|title=Martin Kemp (historien d'art)|website=boowiki.info|language=fr|access-date=2018-06-25}}</ref> This raises the issue of Kemp's credibility and, at least, can lead one to infer that this is not a Leonardo. Some of those who disagree with the attribution to Leonardo believe the portrait is by an early 19th-century German artist imitating the style of the [[Italian Renaissance]], although recent [[radiocarbon dating]] tests show a much earlier date for the vellum. The white lead has been dated to be at least 225 years old. The current owner is Peter Silverman, and the last disclosed offer for the portrait was [[U.S. Dollars|$]]80 million, which was declined by Silverman. The ''Bella Principessa'' remains locked in a vault in a secret Swiss location.<ref name="NOVA Episode">{{cite AV media | people = | date = January 25, 2012 | title = Mystery of a Masterpiece | medium = Television production | url = http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/tech/mystery-masterpiece.html | access-date = July 15, 2018 | publisher = PBS/WGBH |subscription=yes}}</ref>
==Description== The portrait is a [[mixed media]] drawing in pen and brown ink and [[bodycolour]], over red, black and white chalk, on vellum, {{convert|33|by|23.9|cm|sigfig=1}}<ref name="turner">{{cite web|last=Turner|first= Nicholas|title=Statement concerning the portrait on vellum by Leonardo| url=http://www.lumiere-technology.com/images/Download/Nicholas_Turner_Statement.pdf |accessdate=19 November 2012|date=September 2008}}</ref> which has been laid down on an oak board.<ref name=study/> There are three stitch holes in the left-hand margin of the vellum, indicating that the leaf was once in a bound volume.<ref name=study/> It represents a girl in her early teens, depicted in profile, the usual way in which Italian artists of the 15th century created enduring portraits. The girl's dress and hairstyle indicate that she was a member of the Court of Milan during the 1490s.<ref name=MK/> If it truly is a Renaissance work, it would have been executed in the 1490s.<ref name=MK/>
==Provenance== If the drawing is originally a Leonardo illustration for the present-day Warsaw copy of the ''Sforziad'', its history is the same as that of the book until the drawing was cut out from the volume.<ref>See Katarzyna Wozniak, The Warsaw Sforziad http://www.bbk.ac.uk/hosted/leonardo/#MM</ref> The book is known to have been rebound at the turn of the 18 and 19th century.<ref>Katarzyna Wozniak, The Warsaw Sforziad http://www.bbk.ac.uk/hosted/leonardo/#MM</ref><ref>Katarzyna Woźniak, La Bella Principessa and the Warsaw Sforziad. Circumstances of Rebinding and Excision of the Portrait http://www.bbk.ac.uk/hosted/leonardo/#MM</ref>
The modern [[provenance]] of the drawing is known only from 1955 and is documented only from 1998.<ref name="christies"> {{cite web|url=http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=473187 |title=The Head of a young Girl in Profile to the left in Renaissance Dress|work=Lot 402, Sale 8812 ("old master drawings")|author=Christie's|accessdate=15 October 2009|date=1998}}</ref> According to a lawsuit brought by Jeanne Marchig against [[Christie's]] after the drawing's re-attribution to Leonardo, the drawing belonged to her husband Giannino Marchig, an art restorer, when they married in 1955. Jeanne Marchig became the owner of the drawing in 1983, following her husband's death.<ref name="lawsuit">{{cite web|url=http://www.withersworldwide.com/news-publications/bella-principessa-and-the-hazard-of-expert-opinions--2.pdf|date=16 September 2010|author=Whiters LLP|title=Bella Principessa and the hazard of expert opinions|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029191452/http://www.withersworldwide.com/news-publications/bella-principessa-and-the-hazard-of-expert-opinions--2.pdf|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=}}</ref>
The work was included in a sale at Christie's in New York on January 1, 1998, catalogued as ''Young Girl in Profile in Renaissance Dress'', and described as "German School, early 19th Century".<ref name =christies/> The seller was Jeanne Marchig.<ref name="study">{{cite web|url=http://www.lumiere-technology.com//news/Study_Bella_Principessa_and_Warsaw_Sforziad.pdf |last1=Cotte|first1= Pascal |last2=Kemp|first2= Martin|title=''La Bella Principessa'' and the Warsaw ''Sforziad''|publisher=Lumiere Technology|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> It was sold to a New York art dealer for $21,850<ref name=study/> (including buyer's premium).<ref name =christies/> who sold it on for a similar amount in 2007.<ref name=G1/>
Lumière Technology in Paris performed a [[Multi-spectral image|multi-spectral digital scan]] of the work,<ref name="biro">{{cite news | url = https://www.thestar.com/news/world/article/709317---19-000-portrait-could-be-lost-davinci-work | title = $19,000 Portrait Could Be Lost Da Vinci Work | last = McLean | first=Jesse | work = [[Toronto Star]] | date = 13 October 2009 | accessdate = 13 October 2009}}</ref> and in 2009 the spectral images were analysed by Peter Paul Biro, a [[Forensic science|forensic]] art examiner who discovered a [[fingerprint]] which he said was "highly comparable" to a fingerprint on Leonardo's unfinished ''[[Saint Jerome in the Wilderness (Leonardo)|St. Jerome in the Wilderness]]''.<ref name=G1/><ref name="forensic">{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2009/oct/13/leonardo-da-vinci-painting-discovered | title = New Leonardo da Vinci painting 'discovered' | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 13 October 2009 | accessdate = 13 October 2009 | location = London | first = Helen | last = Pidd}}</ref> In 2011 though, the ''New Yorker'' published an article about Paul Biro and revealed he had attempted and succeeded to authenticate many fakes knowingly.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2010/07/12/the-mark-of-a-masterpiece|title=The Prints in the Paint|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref> He was condemned but still "practices".
The drawing was shown in an exhibition called ''And there was Light'' in [[Eriksberg, Gothenburg]] in Sweden,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://svt.se/2.34007/1.1932778/la_bella_principessa_pa_plats?lid=senasteNytt_1765014&lpos=rubrik_1932778|title=''La Bella Principessa'' på plats|work=svt.se|date=March 18, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612074323/http://svt.se/2.34007/1.1932778/la_bella_principessa_pa_plats?lid=senasteNytt_1765014&lpos=rubrik_1932778|archivedate=June 12, 2011|df=}}</ref> and was estimated by various newspaper reports to be worth more than $160 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.antiquestradegazette.com/news/7311.aspx |title=Fingerprint points to $19,000 portrait being revalued as £100m work by Leonardo da Vinci|date= 12 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/europe/10/13/da.vinci.portrait.found/ | publisher = CNN|title=Fingerprint unmasks original da Vinci painting | date=13 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8304021.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]] | title=Finger points to new da Vinci art|date=13 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2009/oct/13/leonardo-da-vinci-painting-discovered | work = [[The Guardian]] | location = London | title = New Leonardo da Vinci painting 'discovered' | first = Helen | last = Pidd | date=13 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/6309942/Leonardo-da-Vinci-picture-worth-millions-revealed-by-a-fingerprint.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | location = London | title = Leonardo da Vinci picture 'worth millions' revealed by a fingerprint | first = Stephen | last = Adams | date = 12 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/visual_arts/article6872019.ece | work = [[The Times]] | location = London | title = Unrecognised Leonardo da Vinci portrait revealed by his fingerprint | first = Ben | last = Hoyle | date=13 October 2009}}</ref>
Reflecting the subject of an Italian woman of high nobility, Kemp named the portrait ''La Bella Principessa'', although Sforza ladies were not [[princess]]es.<ref name= MK/>
==Support for Leonardo Attribution== [[File:Araldi pallavicino.jpg|thumb|A portrait by [[Ambrogio da Predis]] of Beatrice Sforza showing a similar hairstyle]] [[File:Profile of a Young Fiancee - fingerprint.JPG|thumb| Detail of the upper left corner, revealing a [[fingerprint]] which has been suggested as being similar to one of Leonardo's.]] [[File:La Sforziada.jpg|thumb|A page of ''La Sforziada'' from the [[National Library of Poland]] (Biblioteka Narodowa) in [[Warsaw]]]]
The first study of the drawing was published by Cristina Geddo.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Geddo|first= Cristina|title=Il pastello ritrovato: un nuovo ritratto di Leonardo?|journal= Artes|volume= 14|year= 2008–2009|pages= 63–87|url=http://www.lumiere-technology.com/Artes14.pdf}}</ref> Geddo attributes this work to Leonardo based not only on stylistic considerations, extremely high quality and left-handed [[hatching]], but also on the evidence of the combination of black, white and red chalks (the ''[[trois crayons]]'' technique). Leonardo was the first artist in Italy to use pastels, a drawing technique he had learned from the French artist [[Jean Perréal]], whom he met in Milan at the end of the fifteenth century. Leonardo acknowledges his debt to Perréal in the [[Codex Atlanticus]]. Geddo also points out that the "coazzone" of the sitter's hairstyle was fashionable during the same period. Strong support for the attribution has come from Elizabetta Gnignera, the costume historian, in her book ''La Bella Svelata'', which studies a wide range of comparative costumes and hair styles.
===Expert opinions=== A number of Leonardo experts and art historians have concurred with the attribution to Leonardo, including: * Martin Kemp, Emeritus Research Professor in the History of Art at the [[University of Oxford]],<ref name=MK/> who endorsed Paul Biro<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/culture/article/2009/10/14/un-empreinte-digitale-revele-un-nouveau-tableau-de-leonard-de-vinci_1253636_3246.html|title=Un empreinte digitale révèle un nouveau tableau de Léonard de Vinci|website=Le Monde.fr|language=fr|access-date=2018-06-25}}</ref> * [[Carlo Pedretti]], professor emeritus of art history and Armand Hammer Chair in Leonardo Studies at the University of California, Los Angeles<ref name="Pedretti">{{cite web|first=Carlo |last=Pedretti|title= introduction to Alessandro Vezzosi, ''Leonardo Infinito'', Scriptamaneant Editzioni – Bologna, Italy |url=http://www.lumiere-technology.com/images/Download/Abstract_Pr_Pedretti.pdf|date=2008}}</ref> * Nicholas Turner, former curator at the British Museum and the J. Paul Getty Museum<ref name=turner/> * Alessandro Vezzosi, the director of the Museo Ideale Leonardo da Vinci in [[Vinci, Tuscany|Vinci]], Italy<ref name=Vezzosi>Alessandro Vezzosi, ''Nuptial Portrait of a Young Woman''</ref> * Cristina Geddo, an expert on Milanese Leonardesques and [[Giampietrino]],<ref name=silver/> * Mina Gregori, [[Professor emeritus|professor emerita]] at the [[University of Florence]].<ref name=G1 /><ref name="silver">{{citation|first=Peter|last= Silverman |journal=[[The New Yorker]]|date=August 2, 2010|page= 3|title=Re: The Mark of a Masterpiece – A letter in response to David Grann’s article (July 12 & 19, 2010)|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/letters/2010/08/02/100802mama_mail3}}</ref><ref name="E1">Esterow, Milton. [http://www.artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2815 "The Real Thing?"]{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101025204850/http://artnews.com/issues/article.asp?art_id=2815 |date=2010-10-25 }}, in ''[[ARTnews]]''</ref>
===Analysis=== In 2010, after a two-year study of the picture, Kemp published his findings and conclusions in a book, ''La Bella Principessa: The Story of the New Masterpiece by Leonardo da Vinci''.<ref name= MK/> Kemp describes the work as "a portrait of a young lady on the cusp of maturity [which] shows her with the fashionable costume and hairstyle of a Milanese court lady in the 1490s". By process of elimination involving the inner group of young [[House of Sforza|Sforza]] women, Kemp suggested that she is probably Bianca Sforza, the illegitimate (but later legitimized) daughter of [[Ludovico Sforza]] ("Il Moro"), duke of Milan. In 1496, when Bianca was no more than 13, she was married to Galeazzo Sanseverino, captain of the duke's Milanese forces and a patron of Leonardo. Bianca was dead within months of her marriage, having suffered from a stomach complaint (possibly an [[ectopic pregnancy]]). Kemp pointed out that Milanese ladies were often the dedicatees of volumes of poetry on [[vellum]], and that such a portrait of a "beloved lady" would have made a suitable [[title page]] or main illustration for a set of verses produced on the occasion of her marriage or death.<ref name=MK>{{cite book | last1 = Kemp | first1 = Martin |last2=Cotte| first2= Pascal| title = La Bella Principessa: The Story of the New Masterpiece by Leonardo da Vinci | publisher = [[Hodder & Stoughton]] | location = London | year = 2010 | isbn = 978-1-4447-0626-0 }}</ref>
The physical and scientific evidence from multispectral analysis and study of the painting, as described by Kemp,<ref name= MK/> may be summarized as follows: * The technique of the portrait is black, red and white chalks (''[[trois crayons]]'', a French medium), with pen and ink. * The drawing and [[hatching]] was carried out entirely by a left-handed artist, as Leonardo is known to have been, although restorations are by a right-hander. * There are significant [[Pentimento|pentimenti]] throughout. * The portrait is characterized by particularly subtle details, such as the [[relief]] of the ear hinted at below the hair, and the amber of the sitter's iris. * There are strong stylistic parallels with the [[Print Room, Windsor|Windsor]] [[silverpoint]] drawing of ''A Woman in Profile'', which, like other head studies by Leonardo, features comparable delicate pentimenti to the profile. * The members of the Sforza family were always portrayed in profile, whereas Ludovico's mistresses were not. * The proportions of the head and face reflect the rules that Leonardo articulated in his notebooks. * The [[Interlace (visual arts)|interlace]] or knotwork ornament in the costume and [[Caul (headgear)|caul]] corresponds to patterns that Leonardo explored in other works and in the logo designs for his ''Academy''. * The portrait was executed on vellum—used by him in his illustrations for Luca Pacioli's De divina proportione (1498). We know from his writings that he was interested in the French technique of dry colouring on parchment (vellum). He specifically noted that he should ask the French artist, Jean Perréal, who was in Milan in 1494 and perhaps on other occasions, about the method of colouring in dry chalks. * The format of the vellum support is that of a {{radic|2}} rectangle, a format used for several of his portraits. * The vellum sheet was cut from a [[codex]], probably a volume of poetry of the kind presented to mark major events in the Sforza women's lives. * The vellum bears a fingerprint near the upper left edge, which features a distinctive "island" ridge and closely matches a fingerprint in the unfinished ''St Jerome'' by Leonardo. It also includes a palmprint in the chalk pigment on the neck of the sitter, which is characteristic of Leonardo's technique. * The green of the sitter's costume was obtained with a simple diffusion of black chalk applied on top of the yellowish tone of the vellum support. (Kemp has subsequently expressed reservations about this evidence.) * The nuances of the flesh tints were also achieved by exploiting the tone of the vellum and allowing it to show through the transparent media. * There are noteworthy similarities between this work and the portrait of [[Cecilia Gallerani]], including the handling of the eyes, the modelling of flesh tones using the palm of the hand, the intricacy of the patterns of the knotwork ornament and the treatment of the contours. * The now somewhat pale original hatching in pen and ink was retouched in ink in a later restoration, which is far less fluid, precise and rhythmic. * There have been some re-touchings over the years, most extensively in the costume and headdress, but the restoration has not affected the expression and physiognomy of the face to a significant degree, and has not seriously affected the overall impact of the portrait.<ref name= MK/>
===Warsaw copy of the ''Sforziada''=== In 2011, Kemp and Pascal Cotte reported that there was evidence that the drawing had once been part of a copy in the [[National Library of Poland]] in [[Warsaw]] of the ''Sforziada''.<ref>[http://polona.pl/item/1520897/0/] to "turn-the pages" for the Warsaw copy of the ''Sforziada''</ref> This is a printed book with hand-illuminated additions containing a long propagandistic poem in praise of the father of Ludovico Sforza, who was Leonardo's patron, recounting the career. The Warsaw copy, printed on vellum with added illumination, was given to Galeazzo Sanseverino, a military commander under Ludovico Sforza, on his marriage to Bianca Sforza in 1496.<ref name=Lumiere /> Kemp and Cotte identified where two sheets were missing from this volume from which they believe the drawing was cut. Kemp and Cotte say that, although "the dimensions and precise locations of the holes in the portrait cannot be obtained with precision", the three holes on the left-hand side of the drawing can be aligned with three of the five stitch holes in the sheets in the book.<ref name=study/><ref>Kemp and Cotte believe the difference in the number of holes is due either to the irregular way in which the margin of the page with the drawing has been cut, or to the addition of two intermediate stitches when the book was rebound.</ref><ref name="Bambach">{{Cite web|url=http://artwatch.org.uk/tag/carmen-bambach/|title= Carmen Bambach, Artwatch|website=artwatch.org.uk|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
The association with the ''Sforziada'' suggests that the drawing is a portrait of Bianca Sforza, who was the daughter of Ludovico Sforza and his mistress Bernardina de Corradis. At the time of the portrait, she was around thirteen years old. Leonardo painted three other portraits associated with the family or court of Ludovico Sforza.
The Polish scholar Bogdan Horodyski in 1954-1956 reached the conclusion that the Warsaw illumination refers to both the deceased dukes Galeazzo Maria and Gian Galeazzo and to the dynastic downfall after the usurpation of Ludovico il Moro. The reproduction of the unpublished heraldic figure attributed to Antonio Grifo, illuminated in the incunabulum "Comedia" by Dante (Cremonese, Venice 1491), now at Casa di Dante in Rome, shows the original coat of arms and insignia of the family of Galeazzo Sanseverino, and the comparison with those illuminated by Birago is not corresponding. Developing this hypothesis, Carla Glori suggests that Caterina Sforza, the daughter of Galeazzo Maria and half-sister of Gian Galeazzo, was the owner of the Warsaw Sforziad and that she gave it to the family of her deceased half-brother between 1496-1499.<ref>Glori, Carla, [https://www.academia.edu/17531825/The_Illumination_by_Birago_in_the_Sforziad_incunabulum_in_Warsaw_in_defence_of_Horodyski_s_thesis_and_a_new_hypothesis “The Illumination by Birago in the Sforziad incunabulum in Warsaw: in defense of Horodyski's thesis and a new hypothesis”], Academia.edu</ref>
==Opposition for Leonardo Attribution==
The ''New Yorker'' article discussed the troubling circumstances in which Kemp attributed this work to Leonardo. But apart from this, strong indications are going against the hypothesis of authenticity, and the attribution to Leonardo has been challenged by a number of scholars who showed interest.<ref name=G1 /><ref name=E1 /><ref name="D1">{{cite news|last=Dorment|first= Richard |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/7582591/La-Bella-Principessa-a-100m-Leonardo-or-a-copy.html |title=''La Bella Principessa'': a £100m Leonardo, or a copy?|journal=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=12 April 2010}}</ref> Among the reasons for doubting its authorship are the lack of [[provenance]] prior to the 20th century – unusual given Leonardo's renown dating from his own lifetime, as well as the fame of the purported subject's family<ref name=D1 /> – and the fact that it was on vellum. Only once did Leonardo use vellum and old sheets of it are easily acquired by forgers.<ref name=G1 /> Leonardo scholar Pietro C. Marani discounts the significance of the drawing being made by a left-handed artist, noting that imitators of Leonardo's work have emulated this characteristic in the past.<ref name=D1 /> Marani is also troubled by use of vellum, "monotonous" detail, use of colored pigments in specific areas, firmness of touch and lack of [[craquelure]].<ref name=D1 /> A museum director who wished to remain anonymous believes the drawing is "a screaming 20th-century fake", and finds the damages and repair to the drawing suspicious.<ref name=D1 /> The work was not requested for inclusion in the 2011–12 exhibition at the [[National Gallery, London|National Gallery]] in London, which specifically covered Leonardo's period in Milan; [[Nicholas Penny]], director of the [[National Gallery]], said simply "We have not asked to borrow it."<ref name=D1 />
Carlo Pedretti, who is one of the scholars who attribute this work to Leonardo, has had before make a mistake attributing a painting from the twentieth century to the Master.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ansa.it/english/news/lifestyle/arts/2018/01/05/leonardo-expert-pedretti-dies-2_28ae950b-7e37-4bd3-87e4-3b1353f94e2a.html|title=Leonardo expert Pedretti dies (2) - Lifestyle|date=2018-01-05|work=ANSA.it|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en}}</ref> Also, Leonardo never represented eyelashes, in his paintings as well as in his drawings.
{{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | header_align = center | header = | image1 =Gallerani drawing.jpg | width1 = 200 | alt1 = | caption1 =Drawing of a woman by Leonardo. A stylistic similarity has been noted between this drawing and the ''Bella Principessa''.<ref name=Vezzosi/> | image2 = Schnorr von Carolsfeld, Julius-aa Weiblicher Halbakt-a-VELLUM-1 Mannheim.JPG | width2 = 155 | alt2 = | caption2 =Drawing by [[Julius Schnorr von Carolsfeld]] which has been suggested as depicting the same female model }}
[[:de:Klaus Albrecht Schröder|Klaus Albrecht Schröder]], director of the [[Albertina, Vienna]], said "No one is convinced it is a Leonardo," and David Ekserdjian, a scholar of 16th-century Italian drawings, wrote that he suspects the work is a "counterfeit".<ref name=G1 /> Neither Carmen Bambach of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], one of the primary scholars of Leonardo's drawings, nor Everett Fahy, her colleague at the Metropolitan, accepts the attribution to Leonardo.<ref name=G1 /><ref name=D1 /><ref name="Bambach" />
Several forensic experts on fingerprints have discounted Biro's conclusions, finding the partial fingerprint taken from the drawing too poorly detailed to offer conclusive evidence.<ref name=G1 /> Biro's description of the print as being "highly comparable" to a known fingerprint of Leonardo's has similarly been discounted by fingerprint examiners as being too vague an assessment to establish authorship.<ref name=G1 /> When asked if he may have been mistaken to suggest that the fingerprint was Leonardo's, Biro answered "It's possible. Yes."<ref name=G1 />
Noting the lack of mention of dissenting opinion in Kemp's publication, Richard Dorment wrote in the ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Telegraph]]'': "Although purporting to be a work of scholarship, his book has none of the balanced analysis you would expect from such an acclaimed historian. For ''La Bella Principessa'', as he called the girl in the study, is not art history – it is advocacy."<ref name=D1 />
Fred R. Kline, an independent art historian and author of ''Leonardo's Holy Child--The Discovery of a Leonardo da Vinci Masterpiece: A Connoisseur's Search for Lost Art in America'', is known for his discovery of “Leonardo's model drawing” of Infant Jesus (which has yet to be examined by, or accepted or rejected, by Leonardo scholars) and for a number of important discoveries of [[Lost artworks|lost art]] by the [[Nazarene Brotherhood]],<ref name="autogenerated2002">{{cite news|last=Geary|first= David|title=An Art Explorer Finds the Real Creator of Works|journal=New York Times|date= April 2, 2002}}</ref> a group of German painters working in Rome during the early 19th century who revived the styles and subjects of the Italian Renaissance.<ref name="autogenerated2002"/> Kline has proposed one of the Nazarenes, [[Julius Schnorr von Carolsfeld]] (1794–1872), as the creator of the drawing.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sharpe|first= Tom. |title=Case Closed on da Vinci Mystery?|journal=The Santa Fe New Mexican|date= September 25, 2010|url=http://www.santafenewmexican.com/news/local_news/case-closed-on-da-vinci-art-mystery/article_4c31857b-ee41-518b-b60d-044786f9ecd9.html}}</ref> In evidence, Kline points to a drawing on vellum by Schnorr, ''Half-nude Female'', in the collection of the [[Kunsthalle Mannheim]] in Germany,<ref>[[:File:Schnorr von Carolsfeld, Julius-aa Weiblicher Halbakt-a-VELLUM-1 Mannheim.JPG|image of the Mannheim drawing]]</ref> which he suggests depicts the same model, although older, as portrayed in ''La Bella Principessa.''
Comparative material-testing of the vellum supports of the Mannheim Schnorr and ''La Bella Principessa'' were anticipated to occur in the New York federal court lawsuit ''Marchig v. Christie's'', brought in May 2010 by the original owner of ''La Bella Principessa'', who accused Christie's of [[breach of fiduciary duty]], [[negligent misrepresentation]] and other claims. However, the court dismissed the suit on the ground that the claims were brought years too late ([[Statute of Limitations]] and [[Laches (equity)|Laches]]), and thus the merits of the suit were never addressed. The district court decision was upheld on appeal.<ref>[https://casetext.com/case/marchig-v-christies-inc-2 ''Marchig v. Christie's Inc.''], 762 F. Supp. 2d 667 (S.D.N.Y.), ''aff'd in relevant part'', 2011 WL 2685608 (2d Cir. Summary Order July 12, 2011).</ref>
Disagreements with the attribution to Leonardo were made before the discovery of the missing page in the Warsaw Sforziada book. No alternative attribution has been accepted by Kemp or his research group. Kline claims that no comparative scientific analysis has been made of the vellum supports in question: the Warsaw Sforziada book, the Mannheim Schnorr (an alternate attribution), and ''La Bella Principessa,'' although Kemp and Cotte have shown a close match between the vellum of the portrait and the book. Further analysis of the vellum could possibly provide the conclusive evidence that may support or disqualify Leonardo's or Schnorr's authorship.
In November 2015, notorious [[art forger]] [[Shaun Greenhalgh]] claimed that he created the work in 1978, at the age of 20; Greenhalgh said the woman's face is that of a supermarket check-out girl named Alison who worked in Bolton, outside [[Manchester, England|Manchester]].<ref name="Reyburn4Dec">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/07/arts/international/an-art-world-mystery-worthy-of-leonardo.html|title=An Art World Mystery Worthy of Leonardo|date=December 4, 2015|accessdate=December 6, 2015|work=The New York Times|first=Scott|last=Reyburn}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/news/uk_news/Arts/article1639169.ece|title=‘It’s not a da Vinci, it’s Sally from the Co-op’ |work=The Sunday Times}}</ref> In his memoir ''A Forger's Tale'', written in prison, Greenhalgh claims as a 17 year old to have forged the drawing by obtaining an old piece of vellum from a reused 1587 land deed. Kemp said he found the claim hilarious and ridiculous,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://martinkempsthisandthat.blogspot.co.uk/2015/11/the-silly-season-for-leonardo-never.html|title= La Bella Principessa is a "forgery"!!! |date=29 November 2015|publisher=Martin Kemp's This and That|authorlink=Martin Kemp (art historian)|first=Martin|last=Kemp}}</ref> noting that the painting was made with pre-17th century white chalk and stating that it's "hugely unlikely" that Greenhalgh would have known to or been able to obtain sufficient old pigment."<ref>{{cite web| url =http://theartnewspaper.com/news/news/could-leonardo-s-bella-principessa-be-greenhalgh-s-bolton-sally-/| title =Could Leonardo’s Bella Principessa be Greenhalgh’s Bolton Sally?| work =The Art Newspaper| date =30 November 2015| accessdate =30 November 2015| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20151203055958/http://theartnewspaper.com/news/news/could-leonardo-s-bella-principessa-be-greenhalgh-s-bolton-sally-/| archivedate =3 December 2015| df =}}</ref>

revision.comment: /* External links */ A review of 'Limbs Dance Company: Dance For All People 1977-1989' which describes the significance of the company in New Zealand.
revision.text:
The '''Limbs Dance Company''' was formed in Auckland, [[New Zealand]] in May 1977 and disbanded in Wellington in September 1989.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://ausdance.org.au/?ACT=73&file=1050|title=Phantom Limbs: Researching a New Zealand Dance Company|last=Schultz|first=Marianne|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=18 August 2017}}</ref> Limbs was "the first contemporary dance company in New Zealand to win a general following"<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Brief Guide to New Zealand Art & Culture|last=O'Connor|first=Naomi|publisher=Craig Potton Publishing|year=1995|isbn=0908802285|location=Nelson, New Zealand|pages=37}}</ref>, and performed alongside notable New Zealand acts such as [[Split Enz]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nzonscreen.com/title/nambassa-festival-1979|title=Nambassa Festival {{!}} Television {{!}} NZ On Screen|website=www.nzonscreen.com|language=en|others=NZ On Screen|access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref>
Choreographers included [[Mary Jane O'Reilly]], [[Chris Jannides]], [[Mark Baldwin (choreographer)|Mark Baldwin]], [[Douglas Wright (dancer)|Douglas Wright]], Marianne Schultz and Shona McCullagh.<ref name=":0" />
Music for the dances included that by [[Coconut Rough]], [[Split Enz]], [[Schtung]], the [[Topp Twins]], [[Jack Body]], Chris Cree Brown, [[Don McGlashan]], [[Philip Dadson]], Wayne Laird, [[Jan Preston]] and [[Ivan Zagni]]<ref name=":0" />
When the company closed their records were taken to [[Auckland Libraries|Auckland City Library]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aucklandcity.govt.nz/dbtw-wpd/virt-exhib/realgold/Arts/limbs.html|title=Real Gold, Treasures of Auckland Libraries – Arts – Limbs Dance Company. Records (1978-89)|website=www.aucklandcity.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2017-08-18}}</ref>
In September 2017, 40 years since the founding, Marianne Schultz released a comprehensive history of the group entitled ''Limbs Dance Company: Dance For All People, 1977-1989''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU1709/S00419/double-celebration-of-the-legacy-of-limbs-dance-company.htm|title=Double celebration of the legacy of Limbs Dance Company {{!}} Scoop News|website=www.scoop.co.nz|access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref>

The series premiered across Japan on the anime [[satellite television]] network, [[Animax]], as an exclusive [[High-definition video|high definition]] [[communications satellite|CS]]-[[pay per view|PPV]] broadcast, and was also later aired by the network across its other respective networks worldwide, including [[Southeast Asia]], [[South Asia]], [[Latin America]] and other regions. This is a list of known monuments dedicated to [[Joseph Stalin]].
== Albania == * A statue of Joseph Stalin stood in [[Tirana]] but was taken down in December 1990. * A large statue of Stalin, along with one of Lenin, can be found behind the Art Museum in Tirana.
== Armenia == * From November 1950 until spring 1962, a huge Stalin statue was located in [[Yerevan]]. It was replaced in 1967 by [[Mother Armenia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.red-thread.org/en/article.asp?a=33|title=Red Thread - e-journal|first=Red|last=Thread|website=www.red-thread.org}}</ref>
== Czech Republic == * In [[Olomouc]]. * A massive granite [[Stalin Monument (Prague)|statue of Stalin]], the largest depiction of Stalin, stood in [[Letná Park]], [[Prague]] from 1955 to 1962.
== Germany == * A large statue of Stalin raising his right hand was in [[Riesa]]. * A statue of Stalin stood in East Berlin's Stalinallee, 1951–[[1961 |61]].
== Georgia == * Small bust in front of the [[Batumi Stalin Museum]]. * A statue of Stalin stood at the town hall in [[Gori, Georgia|Gori]] until it was taken down in June 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/10412097.stm |title=Stalin statue taken down in his Georgian hometown |work =BBC News | accessdate= 2015-07-09}}</ref> * A Bust and a statue of Stalin was displayed in the [[Joseph Stalin Museum, Gori |Joseph Stalin Museum]] in [[Gori, Georgia|Gori]], but it was destroyed. * A silver statue of Stalin still exists in [[Shovi]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.hansrossel.com/fotos/fotografie/georgie/geo_s26.htm |title= Photos of Republic of Georgia, silver statue of Stalin in the garden park of Shovi (Showshi) Kurort holiday resort |work= Hans Rossel |accessdate= 2015-07-10}}</ref>
== Hungary == * Former [[Stalin Monument (Budapest)|Stalin Monument]] at the edge of [[City Park (Budapest)|Városliget]] in [[Budapest]].
== Lithuania == * In [[Grutas Park]].
== Mongolia == *A statue of Stalin stands at Isimuss Club in [[Ulaanbaatar]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/mikeemesser/2816444175/|title=Stalin Statue at Isimuss Club, Ulaanbaatar|work=Flickr.com|accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> *A statue of Stalin stood at front of the [[National Library of Mongolia]] until 1991.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/felibrilu/4192059196/|title=National Library|work=Flickr.com|accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref><ref>C. Amarcanaa and C. Mainbayar ''Concise Historical Album of the Mongolian Democratic Union''. 2009. Illustration, p. 74</ref> It was replaced by a statue of [[Byambyn Rinchen]].
== The Netherlands == * A statue of Stalin waist deep in a pond, spitting water is displayed in Sonsbeek Park, [[Arnhem]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/hoenen/2581382590/|title=Josef Stalin Statue in the water|work=Flickr.com|accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref>
== Poland == * A [[Ustrzyki Dolne]] statue 1951–[[1956 |56]]. As the result of the [[1951 Polish–Soviet territorial exchange]] Poland obtained Ustrzyki Dolne, where Stalin's statue existed. The statue was unpopular, dressed, decorated with sausages or a broom and finally removed in 1956.<ref>{{Citation | title = Niezwykła historia pomnika Stalina w Ustrzykach | newspaper = Nowiny 24 | language = pl | url = http://www.nowiny24.pl/reportaze/art/6127707,niezwykla-historia-pomnika-stalina-w-ustrzykach,id,t.html}}.</ref> * [[Kraków]] - with [[Vladimir Lenin]], in Strzelecki Park, removed in 1957<ref>{{cite web|url=http://encyklopedia.pwn.pl/haslo/Krakow-pomnik-Stalina-i-Lenina-w-Parku-Strzeleckim;4689146.html|title=Kraków, pomnik Stalina i Lenina w Parku Strzeleckim - Encyklopedia PWN - źródło wiarygodnej i rzetelnej wiedzy|website=encyklopedia.pwn.pl}}</ref>
== Romania == * A statue of Stalin stood at the entrance of ''Parcul I. V. Stalin'' (now renamed [[Herăstrău Park|Parcul Herăstrău]]) in Bucharest but was torn down in 1956 during the [[De-Stalinization in Romania]]. * A statue was located in front of the Central Party Comitee Building (today the Prefecture) in [[Brașov]] but was torn down in 1956 during the [[De-Stalinization in Romania]].
== Russia == * Many statues can be found at [[Fallen Monument Park]], [[Moscow]]. * Bust at his tomb in the [[Kremlin Wall Necropolis#Individual tombs, 1948–1985|Kremlin Wall Necropolis]], Moscow. * Bust in the [[Museum of the Great Patriotic War, Moscow|Museum of the Great Patriotic War]], Moscow.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tl.advisor.travel/photo_ex/107064|title=Bust of Joseph Stalin, Museum of the Great Patriotic War, Moscow by Watersling|work=Advisor.Travel|accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> * Statue of Stalin along with [[Franklin Roosevelt]] and [[Winston Churchill]] at the [[All-Russia Exhibition Center]], Moscow. * A large Stalin statue stood at the [[All-Russia Exhibition Centre#1935-1939 construction|All-Russia Exhibition Center]] until 1948. * A large statue of Stalin (created in 1952 by sculptor E.V. Vuchetich) stood in a southern suburb of Volgograd until 1961. A huge statue of Lenin, created by the same sculptor, was set up in the same spot and on the same base in 1972. * A bust stands at the Memorial of Glory in [[Vladikavkaz]]. * A bust stands at School No. 2 in [[Ardon, North Ossetia–Alania|Ardon, North Ossetia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kprf.ru/rus_soc/62252.html|title=Северная Осетия: 129 день рождения И.В.Сталина в Северной Осетии|work=Kprf.ru|accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref> * There is bust of Stalin in the Communist Party's regional headquarters in [[Bryansk]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.regnum.ru/news/1237431.html |title=В Брянске торжественно открыт бюст Сталина. |publisher=Regnum.ru |date=2009-12-22 |accessdate=2015-07-09}}</ref> * A bust of Stalin is in [[Kizel]]. * A statue in {{Interlanguage link multi|Nogir|ru|3=Ногир}}, [[North Ossetia–Alania]]. * A statue of Stalin is in the yard of School No.2, [[Ardon, Republic of North Ossetia–Alania|Ardon, North Ossetia–Alania]]. * A bust of Stalin in the village of [[Chokh]], Dagestan. * A bust of Stalin at a square in [[Derbent]], Dagestan.
== Tajikistan == * A Stalin statue stands at a [[nursery school]] in [[Asht]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Last_Man_Standing/2085185.html|title=Last Man Standing?|work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref>
== Ukraine == * A bust of Stalin was exhibited in front of the [[Communist Party of Ukraine|Communist Party of Ukraine's]] headquarters in [[Zaporizhya]] in 2010 but it was destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-48257020100505|title=New Stalin statue fuels tension in Ukraine|work=Reuters.com|accessdate=2015-07-10}}</ref>
== United States == * A bust of Stalin was removed in 2010 at the [[National D-Day Memorial]] in [[Bedford, Virginia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailysignal.com/2010/09/29/d-day-memorial-board-to-relocate-stalin-sculpture/|title=D-Day Memorial Board to Relocate Stalin Sculpture|website=www.dailysignal.com}}</ref>

'''Margareta Birgersdotter Grip''' (1538–1586), was a Swedish baroness, writer and landowner. She is known for her writing: she copied letters and documents from the Middle Ages, the originals of which have since been lost, and for her genealogical research. Genealogical works became common among the nobility after her day, and her work is considered the first of the genre in Sweden.
==Life== She was born to ''[[riksråd]]'' baron Birger Nilsson Grip and Brita Joachimsdotter Brahe. In 1562, she married the noble Erik Månsson [[Natt och Dag]], son of Måns Johansson and [[Barbro Eriksdotter]]. She was thereby the sister-in-law of the lady-in-waiting [[Karin Gyllenstierna]], who were also her neighbor on the estate [[Säby]]. After being widowed shortly after, she managed the estate [[Brokind Castle]] on behalf of her minor son Erik Eriksson Natt och Dag (d. 1566). After the death of her son, she inherited the Bro estate personally. In 1571, she married riksråd [[Sten Axelsson Banér]]. However, she remained the sole manager of the Bro estate.
Traditionally, Margareta Birgersdotter Grip has been named [[Mistress of the Robes]] of Queen [[Karin Månsdotter]] in 1567-1568. However, [[Elin Andersdotter]] is confirmed to have had that position.<ref>Sture Arnell (1951). Karin Månsdotter. Stockholm: Wahlström & Widstrand. ISBN</ref>
Margareta Grip copied a large amount of documents and letters from the Middle Ages, whose originals have since been lost, and who are therefore important historical documents. She produced a genealogical work, with the intent of vindicating her ancestor, [[Bo Jonsson Grip]], a work she started in 1574. Genealogical research became common among the nobility in the late 16th century, but Grip are regarded as the pioneer of this genre in Sweden. Her work is kept at the [[Trolleholm Castle]] archive.

{{Infobox person | name = Maria Morris Miller | image = MariaMorrisNovaScotiaArchives.png | occupation = Artist | image_size = 180px | caption = | nationality = {{flagicon|Canada}} [[Canadians|Canadian]] | birth_place = [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]] | birth_date = February 12, 1813 | death_date = October 29, 1875 | death_place = [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]] | spouse = Garrett Miller | parents = Guy and Sybilla Morris | known_for = Botanical lithographs | children = }}
'''Maria Morris Miller''' (1813-1875) was a Canadian artist from [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]] who is known for her botanical paintings and illustrations. She is also the first professional woman artist in Nova Scotia, recognized in her field during her active career years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/maria-morris-miller/|title=Maria Morris Miller|website=thecanadianencyclopedia.ca|access-date=2018-03-31}}</ref> She worked with scientists and government officials, garnering her accolades as the "Audubon of Nova Scotian field flowers".<ref name="journals.msvu.ca">http://journals.msvu.ca/index.php/atlantis/article/viewFile/4155/3399</ref>
==Career== Born into a middle class family, Miller's mother Sybilla encouraged her to learn about art.<ref>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=kAS6AAAAIAAJ&q=Maria+Morris+Miller&dq=Maria+Morris+Miller |title=Social History |volume=30 |page=11 |publisher=University of Ottawa Press |year=1997}}</ref> Miller studied her craft in Halifax under the tutelage of a visiting British painter named L'Estrange. She also studied with W.H. Jones, a Bostonian who taught at [[Dalhousie College]].<ref>https://books.google.ca/books?id=UgrrAAAAMAAJ&q=Maria+Morris+Miller&dq=Maria+Morris+Miller&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjt2qHaz5faAhXs7YMKHZdkCIw4ChDoAQgtMAE</ref> In 1830, she began offering drawing classes to female students which gave her some financial independence.<ref>https://books.google.ca/books?id=4LW7y8EQQUcC&pg=PA24&dq=Maria+Morris+Miller&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjioNLzzJfaAhWE3oMKHVjUCvMQ6AEITDAG#v=onepage&q=Maria%20Morris%20Miller&f=false</ref><ref name="books.google.ca">https://books.google.ca/books?id=W9DpsO-tjKYC&q=Maria+Morris+Miller&dq=Maria+Morris+Miller&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjt2qHaz5faAhXs7YMKHZdkCIw4ChDoAQhBMAU</ref> The North British Society of Halifax honoured her with the title of "Painter of the Year" in 1836.<ref name =nsgallery>https://artgalleryofnovascotia.ca/maria-morris-miller/</ref>
Soon after, Nova Scotia's Secretary of Agriculture and botanist, Titus Smith, asked Miller to paint a series of canvasses depicting local wildflowers. He brought her specimens which she quickly had to immortalize, before the plants deteriorated.<ref name="journals.msvu.ca"/> During the mid 1830s, aided by Smith's scientific input, Miller produced a large number of water colour drawings which later ended up in an important Halifax art exhibition in 1848.<ref name=nsgallery/>
Smith provided botanical descriptions for Miller's first catalog of coloured [[lithograph]]s entitled ''Wild Flowers of Nova Scotia''.<ref>https://books.google.ca/books?id=2OoBMQAACAAJ&dq=Maria+Morris+Miller&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjioNLzzJfaAhWE3oMKHVjUCvMQ6AEIQTAE</ref><ref>https://books.google.ca/books?id=LRQ1AQAAMAAJ&q=Maria+Morris+Miller&dq=Maria+Morris+Miller&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjioNLzzJfaAhWE3oMKHVjUCvMQ6AEIWzAJ</ref><ref>http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio.php?id_nbr=5175</ref> It was issued in 1840 by a London bookseller and local publisher, with the financial support of the province's [[lieutenant-governor]] [[Sir Colin Campbell]]. Two other sets of lithographs followed in 1853 and 1866. The second publication was also issued as ''Wild Flowers of Nova Scotia''. The third catalog was entitled ''Wild Flowers of Nova Scotia and New Brunswick'' and was annotated by [[George Lawson (botanist)|George Lawson]], a botanist who founded the Botanical Society of Canada.<ref name=nsgallery/><ref>https://www.google.ca/search?q=Maria+Morris+Miller&rlz=1C1CHBF_enCA703CA703&tbm=bks&ei=YgrAWuLnGoS9jwTYqKuYDw&start=10&sa=N&biw=907&bih=425&dpr=1.5</ref> In 1867, the first series was reissued with a new title, ''Wild Flowers of British North America''. With her four catalogs, Miller was able to document 22 native plants, at a time when there was an increasing interest in natural history.<ref>https://books.google.ca/books?id=iv95AAAAMAAJ&q=Maria+Morris+Miller&dq=Maria+Morris+Miller&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjt2qHaz5faAhXs7YMKHZdkCIw4ChDoAQgzMAI</ref><ref name="nsgallery"/>
In 1862, Miller participated in an International Exhibition in [[London]], [[England]]. Although her drawings arrived too late to be part of the competition, she received positive reviews in the English press.<ref>https://cwahi.concordia.ca/sources/artists/displayArtist.php?ID_artist=70</ref> In 1867, a copy of her botanical paintings were exhibited at the [[Exposition Universelle (1867)|Paris Exposition]].
Miller's works are part of the permanent collection at the [[Art Gallery of Nova Scotia]], Atlantic Canada's largest art museum.<ref>https://artgalleryofnovascotia.ca/collection/permanent</ref> Other paintings and lithographs are owned by The Nova Scotia Museum of Natural History, also located in Halifax. [[Ottawa]]'s [[National Gallery of Canada]] has some of her lithographs as well, belonging to the 1840 and 1853 series.<ref>https://www.gallery.ca/collection/artist/maria-morris-miller</ref>
Also a writer, Miller published a volume of poetry, ''Metrical Musings'', with her sister Catherine in 1856.<ref>[https://books.google.ca/books?id=TdsCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PR3&lpg=PR3&dq=Metrical+musings+morris&source=bl&ots=rIyrvATJ0n&sig=aBGe28a9jfg0qyz3waZzIpsuoKQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj7i4HTzsXOAhUDRCYKHTqDAP8Q6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=Metrical%20musings%20morris&f=false Metrical Musings]</ref>
==Personal life== Most records indicate that Maria Morris Miller was born in 1813 in [[City of Halifax|Halifax, Nova Scotia]], the daughter of Captain Guy Morris and Sibylla Amelia Maria Sophia Leggett. Her father, who was a descendent of [[Charles Morris (jurist)|Charles Morris]], died when Maria was a small child. (She may have also been born in 1810 in Country Harbour, Nova Scotia with her mother moving the family to Halifax after her father's death in 1813.) In 1840, Maria Morris Miller married Garret Trafalgar Nelson Miller, the son of [[Garrett Miller (politician)|Garrett Miller]] and Catherine Pernette, who was the daughter of [[Joseph Pernette]]. Maria Morris Miller and her husband had five children.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Morris, Maria Frances Ann (Miller) |encyclopedia=Dictionary of Canadian Biography |url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio.php?id_nbr=5175 |access-date=January 18, 2018}}</ref><ref name="books.google.ca"/> She passed away in Halifax in 1875.
== Gallery == <gallery widths="180px" heights="180px" perrow="4"> Image:Wild Flowers of Nova Scotia Epigoea repens. May Flower (Plate I).jpg|''Wild Flowers of Nova Scotia: Epigoea repens. May Flower (Plate I)'', 1840, [[National Gallery of Canada]] Image:Wild Flowers of Nova Scotia Sarracenia purpurea. Indian Cup (Plate IV).jpg|''Wild Flowers of Nova Scotia: Sarracenia purpurea. Indian Cup (Plate IV)'', 1840, [[National Gallery of Canada]] </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{refimprove|date=September 2013}} [[File:Sacul vase.jpg|thumb|right|Painted Classic Period vase from [[Sacul, El Petén|Sacul]] in Guatemala]] '''Maya ceramics''' are ceramics produced in the [[Pre-Columbian]] [[Mayan civilization|Maya]] culture of [[Mesoamerica]]. The vessels used different shapes, colors, sizes, and had varied purposes. Vessels for the elite could be painted with very detailed scenes, while utilitarian vessels were undecorated or much simpler. Elite pottery, usually in the form of straight-sided beakers called "vases", used for drinking chocolate, was placed in burials, giving a number of survivals in good condition. Individual examples include the [[Princeton Vase]] and the [[Fenton Vase]].
Used for a plethora of daily activities, such as the storage of food and beverages, [[ceramics (art)|ceramics]] were also a canvas of commemoration. There were three main types of ceramics used in daily life: bowls, plates, and cylinders. They were often [[monochrome]], meaning that only one type of mineral slip was used.<ref name=":0" /> Polychrome pottery was more complex in nature and therefore more commonly used by the elite. Not only was polychrome pottery used as decoration, it was also used as a form of social currency-- a physical display of status and others' approval.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/28632069|title=Painting the Maya universe : royal ceramics of the classic period|last=Dorie.|first=Reents-Budet,|date=1994|publisher=Duke University Press in association with Duke University Museum of Art|others=Ball, Joseph W., Duke University. Museum of Art., Jay I. Kislak Reference Collection (Library of Congress)|isbn=9780822314387|location=Durham|oclc=28632069}}</ref>
As time progressed, various features were added to ceramics to go beyond the fundamental needs of vessels; For example pellets were put in larger bowls to not only serve as something to hold food, but would also become instruments used in the same feasts.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/mayac/hd_mayac.htm|title=Ancient Maya Painted Ceramics {{!}} Essay {{!}} Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History {{!}} The Metropolitan Museum of Art|last=Doyle|first=Author: James|website=The Met’s Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History|access-date=2017-11-10}}</ref>
Archaeological evidence has been found that suggests ceramics were used for industrial purposes. The discovery of highly uniform ceramic cylinders along with tools used in the production of salt indicate that the ceramics were used to mass produce salt from brine.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Robinson|first=Mark|last2=McKillop|first2=Heather|date=Spring 2014|title=Fuelling the Ancient Maya Salt Industry|url=|journal=Economic Botany|volume=68|issue=1|pages=96–108|doi=10.1007/s12231-014-9263-x|via=}}</ref>
==Decoration== The utilitarians ware of the common people usually had simple decoration that reflected its use. For example, cylindrical bowls used for cacao drinks often had the plant species ''Q. guatemalteca'' depicted on them because that flower was used to enhance the flavor of the cacao drink.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Zidar, C. & Elisens, W. Econ Bot|first=|date=June 2009|title=Sacred Giants: Depiction of Bombacoideae on Maya Ceramics in Mexico, Guatemala, and Belize|url=https://doi.org/10.1007/s12231-009-9079-2|journal=Economic Botany|volume=63|pages=119–129|via=|doi=10.1007/s12231-009-9079-2}}</ref> Designs often included rituals, supernatural figures or common day practices. Rulers were often depicted next to deities and shown to be equal, or nearly equal, in power and status as them. Other pots functioned more as storytelling devices, with glyphs from the [[Maya script]] that likely were guides for songs or other ritualistic texts.<ref name=":1" />
For many potters, decoration and imagery was more important than the structure of each vessel.<ref name=":2" /> Cylindrical vases and plates were popular because they maximized the surface area for storytelling through imagery on each piece. There was more evolution in pictorial representations than shapes. As the complexity of painting increased, vessel shapes remained fairly simple.<ref name=":1" />
== Ceramics in society == Maya ceramics are made from two main types of materials that relate to their social structure, [[limestone]] and volcanic ash. Most of the land around the Mayans was limestone, which is where [[calcite]] comes from. These were mainly made as gifts and given to make local alliances, and these vessels are found in a more localized area. Whereas the ones made from volcanic ash are more widespread because they were thought to be given as gifts from the upper class to make very large alliances, through the Maya trade systems. <ref>{{Cite book|title=The production and exchange of moulded-carved ceramics and the ‘Maya Collapse|last=Ting|first=Carmen|publisher=Journal of Archaeological Science|year=2015|isbn=|location=Mo S&T Library|pages=}}</ref>
Ceramics play a big role in society during the [[Maya Classic Period]], when the Maya elite used ceramics not only to give gifts to foreign dignitaries, but they were also used in feasts during the Classic Period. Specialized pottery was made for the graves of nobles. Not anyone could make this pottery as it was very important they knew about the Maya history, mythology, and more. On these ceramics, intricate scenes were depicted which showed the palace life of the elite. On each ceramic piece near the rim, its contents would be listed out, a type of beverage for a vase or food for a plate, then who it belonged to was written next. Since these ceramics were traded and gifted, many end up in differing environments. Specialists mainly pay attention to the writing, drawings, and heiroglyphs, since they were different for the different people and cultures they were made by.<ref>{{Cite book|title=What Can We Learn From a Maya Vase?|last=Reents-Budet|first=Dorie|publisher=Archaeological Institute of America|year=2003|isbn=|location=Mo S&T Library|pages=}}</ref> As for the everyday use more simple ware was made, generally of only one color, and would be produced in large quantities for the general public use.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Specialization, Exchange and Complex Societies|last=Brumfiel|first=Elizabeth|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1987|isbn=|location=Google Books|pages=78-80}}</ref>
== Production techniques == [[Image:Mayanvase.jpg|230px|right|thumb|Maya vase depicting a costumed noble; burial offering. Late classical period (600-900 CE). [[Copán]], [[Honduras]].]]
The Maya had specific techniques to create, inscribe, paint, and design [[pottery]]. To begin creating a ceramic vessel the Maya had to locate the proper resources for [[clay]] and [[temper (mineral)|temper]]. The present-day [[indigenous peoples|indigenous]] Maya, who currently live in [[Guatemala]], [[Belize]] and southern [[Mexico]] still create wonderful ceramics. [[Prudence M. Rice]] provides a look at what the current Guatemalan Maya use today for clay. Highland Guatemala has a rich geological history comprised mainly from a [[volcano|volcanic]] past. The [[metamorphic rock|metamorphic]] and [[igneous]] rock, as well as the sand and ash from the pumice areas provide many types of tempering. In the area, there are a range of clays that create varied colors and strengths when fired. Today's Maya locate their clays in the exposed [[river]] systems of the highland valleys. It is hypothesized that the ancient people obtained their clay by the same method as today's Maya. The clays are located in exposed river systems of the highland valleys. Most likely, due to the climatic similarities over the last millennia it is likely that these same deposits or similar ones could have been used in early times.
Once the [[clay]] and temper were collected, pottery creation began. The maker would take the clay and mix it with the temper (the rock pieces, ash, or sand). Temper served as a strengthening device for the pottery. Once worked into a proper consistency, the shape of the piece was created.
A [[potter's wheel]] was not used in creating this pottery. Instead, they used coil and slab techniques. The coil method most likely involved the formation of clay into long coiled pieces that were wound into a vessel. The coils were then smoothed together to create walls. The slab method used square slabs of clay to create boxes or types of additions like feet or lids for vessels. Once the pot was formed into the shape, then it would have been set to dry until it was leather hard. Then, the pot was painted, inscribed, or slipped. The last step was the firing of the vessel. Kilns were used to fire the vessels, and they were normally found outside in the open air. Unlike many modern kilns, they were fired by wood, charcoal, or even grass.
Like the [[Ancient Greece|Ancient Greeks]], the Maya created clay slips from a mixture of clays and [[mineral]]s. The clay slips were then used to decorate the pottery. By the fourth century, a broad range of colors including yellow, purple, red, and orange were being made. However, some Mayan painters refrained from using many colors and used only black, red, and occasionally cream. This series of ceramics is termed the "[[Codex]]-style", it being similar to the style of the Pre-Columbian [[book]]s.
From the 5th century onwards, post-firing [[stucco]] was adopted from [[Teotihuacan]]. By preparing a thin [[quicklime]], the Maya added mineral pigments that would dissolve and create rich blues and greens that added to their artistic culture. Many times this post-fire stucco technique was mixed with painting and incising. Incising is carving deeply or lightly into partially dried clay to create fine detailed designs. This technique was mostly popular during the Early Classic Period.
==Development chronology== [[File:Incense Burner with Face and Side Flanges, Classic Mayan, highland Guatemala - San Diego Museum of Man - DSC06837.JPG|thumb|[[Incense Burner]] with face and side flanges, [[Classic Mayan]], highland [[Guatemala]], [[San Diego Museum of Man]].]] The Maya were a diverse people whose culture has developed through the centuries. As they developed, so did their pottery. Archaeologists have found stages of commonality between types of ceramics, and these phases coincide with the Mayan timeline.
Middle Preclassic (900/800-250 BC) Late Preclassic (250 BC- AD 250) Early Mayan ceramics stemmed from a past that began even years before the Maya became a group. Originally, the early Maya used [[gourd]]s cut into useful shapes to create vessels to carry liquids and foodstuffs. These portable and durable gourds made excellent containers. The first ceramics closely resembled gourds and many were decorated with rocker stamps and simple slips. During the Late Preclassic period, many of the ceramics took on appendages of tetrapod mammiform supports. These supports were four legs underneath the pot holding it up. Tetrapods are relatively rare in the Maya Lowlands- even in the Peten where they were first described. Characteristic cream-on-red stripes colored these unique vessels.
The pottery of the Maya Early Classic dated from AD 250 to 550. The Maya soon began using polychrome slip paint, meaning they used many different colors to decorate the pots. This method of decoration became almost homogeneous for Mayan potters, thus signaling the beginning of the Classic Period. Polychrome pottery was a luxury item not commonly available to the general population. Most Early Classic Ceramics were monochrome types. Figural Polychromes were an elite prerogative, probably produced by and for other elites. The Classic Period of the Maya provided beautiful ceramics in many forms. The lidded basal flange bowl was a new style of potter to add to the already growing repertoire. This type vessel usually had a knob on top in the form of an animal or human head, while the painted body of the animal or human spreads across the pot. Many of these pots also had mammiform supports, or legs. These unique vessels are usually found in great condition signaling a ritual function. The reason many are in good condition is their frequent use as burial goods. As such, they are often the target of looters who cut deep trenches through many Maya buildings in search of a marketable vessel. {{clear}}
==Sample timelines== [[Image:Chama Style Vessel, Maya Art and Architecture, 1999.jpg|300px|right|thumb|Chama Style Vessel.]] There is no 'standard' timetable for Maya ceramics.
